Award.AwardTitle: The 2017 National Breath of Life Archival Institute for Indigenous Languages

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Native American Languages Act, passed by the U.S. Congress in 1990, enacted into policy the recognition of the unique status and importance of Native American Languages. All Native American languages are endangered, and over 120 of these languages have gone silent, which means there are no remaining fluent first language speakers. Experts recognize around 7,000 languages worldwide, and they estimate at least half will fall silent by the end of this century. Human language is highly complex and scientists have thus far only scratched the surface in analyzing and understanding the scientific diversity represented in the grammars of the individual 7,000 languages. Because the number of languages far exceeds the number of trained language scientists, one challenge is to train more linguists. Another challenge is reversing language endangerment, thus staunching the loss of languages, cultures and knowledge. Opportunities within linguistics that use informal science learning in linguistics, such as short workshops, conferences, and other training, have proven effective in addressing both challenges. One such project, the Breath of Life archival model, has been successful in engaging Native American citizen scientists to work with archival language documentation in repositories in California, Oklahoma and Washington, D.C. This project will fund the 2017 National Breath of Life Archival Institute for Indigenous Languages (National BoL), the fourth of its kind since 2011. Broader impacts include the training of Native American citizen scientists to work on their own tribe's language and the training of linguistics graduate students, who serve as mentors and learn from their experiences how to produce documentation that is both better and more relevant and useful to community language efforts. The general public, other tribal members and interested scholars will also benefit from access to the newly digitized archival materials from the Smithsonian Institution's holdings created as part of this project.

Co-hosted by the Smithsonian's National Anthropological Archives and National Museum of the American Indian, and the Library of Congress, the National BoL will last two weeks and introduce linguistics and the language sciences. Participants are grouped by their heritage language, with each group assigned an academically trained linguist for one-on-one mentoring in the analysis of archival materials in that language. Ultimately, these efforts by citizen scientists will increase their linguistic understanding of their languages, to support reclamation and further investigation of the languages. The National BoL will train citizen scientists from some 15 language communities, bringing the cumulative number of languages investigated in these national workshops to over 70. By engaging community members in research, this workshop broadens the participation of Native Americans in the social sciences by investigating aspects of language that directly benefit community goals. Importantly, the 2017 National BoL will also use professional evaluators to quantitatively and qualitatively assess the extent to which training targeted at capacity building in archival research enables community members to address critical needs in sustaining languages and continue to contribute to the language sciences. Finally, the informal science learning environment provided by the National BoL has the potential to show how it facilitates novel discoveries in linguistics as researchers engage with archival language documentation, while also training new cohorts of academic and community linguists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Breath of Life (NBoL) Institute for Indigenous Languages builds durable collaborative relationships between linguists, archivists and heritage language learners. The Institute plays a critical role in helping  these citizen scientists to discover little used archival materials by providing them with training in the fields of linguistics and language revitalization necessary for their revitalization efforts. Participants leverage archival collections located in the DC area in order to support language revitalization efforts in their own communities. The 2017 BoL Institute hosted twenty eight (24) community researchers representing seventeen (16) different language communities. Together with their nineteen (17) linguistic partners they spent two (2) weeks learning how to access archives and locate resources on their individual languages.

 

Community researchers received instruction in a variety of topics in linguistics including phonetics, phonology and syntax, and were exposed to a wide range of revitalization issues including pedagogy, home strategies and the use of relevant technology.  They worked closely with their linguistic partners learning how to extract and analyse important linguistic and cultural information from archival sources. The Institute culminated in participant presentations to the larger BoL group, sharing their discoveries in the archival materials, and their new knowledge of how to use and interpret them. Many expressed the certainty that the materials and their new skills will inform their language revitalization efforts for years to come.

 

At the start of BoL, participants are provided with digital copies of representative samples of the archival collections at the National Anthropological Archives (NAA) that are relevant to their languages. Participants are therefore able to work hands on with archival materials from day one. In addition, participants have the opportunity to review in person all the holdings related to their languages and can request additional digital copies at the end of the institute. Participants are also exposed to a wealth of knowledge that can be regenerated through research on ethnographic collections. By the end of BoL 2017, an estimated 3,425 pages of archival manuscripts were digitized and made available to participants in high resolution archival TIFFs or PDFs. In addition, participants received any additional digital copies related to their languages of interest that may have been ready in digital format prior to the institute.

 

During BoL, participants gain knowledge about the available archival resources as well as the gaps in archival documentation. This encourages future research and documentation ultimately filling the knowledge gap. BoL participants, as a result of their participation in the institute, become particularly well positioned for receiving the support from BoL organizational partner Recovering Voices at the Smithsonian?s National Museum of Natural History to return to the Smithsonian collections for further research under the Community Research Program. Further, sustained relationships are generated between BoL citizen scientists and the Smithsonian?s research and curatorial staff to further foster revitalization through collections research.

 

Another important outcome of the BoL Institute is the intertribal networking that takes place, and collaboration between language communities and their linguistic partners, which in many cases are new. There are documented examples of BoL participants who eventually go off to enroll in college level linguistic programs or continue expanding their knowledge and experiences by attending other language based workshops and programs, which further their ability to advance community language revitalization efforts. In many cases, it was through the BoL experience that community researchers and linguistic partners meet forming lasting bonds that serve to strengthen communal efforts to document and revitalize their languages.  

 

The BoL experience broadens participants working knowledge of the importance of archives in documenting and revitalizing languages for current and future use. For many, this experience is transformative. Nothing sums up better the overall BoL experience than a comment made by a participating community in this years program:

 

?Such a beneficial program for myself and so many other folks from different tribes/nations around North America. I feel BoL is one of the only initiatives I have seen that is truly making a difference in furthering the revitalization of so many endangered languages.?
